title: Drug-Resistant Epilepsy
scope: ** Management of drug-resistant epilepsy defined as failure of adequate trials of two or more appropriately chosen and tolerated antiseizure medications (ASMs) at adequate doses. Covers advanced pharmacotherapy, presurgical evaluation, surgical options, neuromodulation (VNS, RNS, DBS), dietary therapies, and special populations. Excludes initial seizure workup (see New Onset Seizure), acute breakthrough seizures in known epilepsy (see Breakthrough Seizure), and status epilepticus management (see Status Epilepticus template).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Verify therapeutic levels and adherence; subtherapeutic levels are the most common correctable cause of apparent drug resistance
Essential/Core Labs.target: Therapeutic ranges (see Appendix A); document steady-state trough levels

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Protein-bound drugs require free levels in hypoalbuminemia, renal failure, pregnancy, polypharmacy; free fraction is pharmacologically active
Essential/Core Labs.target: Free phenytoin 1-2 mcg/mL; free valproate 5-15 mcg/mL

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline for ASM hematologic effects; infection as seizure precipitant; monitor for bone marrow suppression (carbamazepine, felbamate)
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; leukopenia <3000 → evaluate ASM cause; aplastic anemia screening for felbamate

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Electrolyte abnormalities; hepatic function (ASM metabolism, toxicity); renal function (ASM dosing); hyponatremia (carbamazepine/oxcarbazepine)
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; hyponatremia <130 → provokes seizures; elevated LFTs → ASM hepatotoxicity

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypomagnesemia lowers seizure threshold; chronic ASM use may deplete magnesium
Hypocalcemia can cause seizures; enzyme-inducing ASMs accelerate vitamin D metabolism
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal ionized Ca; low → check vitamin D, replete

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypoglycemia is reversible seizure cause; GLUT1 deficiency syndrome causes DRE with low CSF glucose
Essential/Core Labs.target: 70-180 mg/dL; persistent low → evaluate GLUT1 deficiency

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: UTI as occult seizure precipitant; especially in elderly and institutionalized patients
Illicit substances lower seizure threshold; assess adherence and drug interactions
Essential/Core Labs.target: Negative; positive → evaluate contribution to seizure frequency

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Pregnancy alters ASM levels; teratogenicity concerns with many ASMs used in DRE (valproate, topiramate, phenobarbital)
Essential/Core Labs.target: Document result; positive → urgent ASM safety review

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Valproate-induced hyperammonemic encephalopathy; can occur with normal LFTs and therapeutic levels
Essential/Core Labs.target: <35 μmol/L; elevated → consider valproate reduction or carnitine supplementation

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Enzyme-inducing ASMs (phenytoin, carbamazepine, phenobarbital) accelerate vitamin D metabolism → osteoporosis; long-term DRE patients at high risk
Phenytoin and carbamazepine deplete folate; B12 deficiency neuropathy; critical for women of childbearing potential
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal; low folate → supplement (5 mg/day with enzyme inducers)

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Thyroid dysfunction affects seizure threshold; some ASMs affect thyroid function
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal; abnormal → treat and reassess seizure frequency

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Enzyme-inducing ASMs increase lipid levels; cardiovascular risk in chronic DRE
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal; elevated → statin if indicated; consider non-enzyme-inducing ASM

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Active metabolite elevated by valproate co-therapy; toxicity with normal parent drug levels
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: <9 mcg/mL; elevated → toxicity even with therapeutic carbamazepine level

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Pharmacogenomic testing before carbamazepine/oxcarbazepine in Asian populations (HLA-B*15:02 → SJS/TEN); HLA-A*31:01 in Europeans
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Negative for risk alleles; positive → avoid associated ASM

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Distinguish epileptic seizure from PNES if diagnostic uncertainty; must draw within 20 min of event
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: 2-3x baseline within 20 min of convulsive seizure; normal in PNES

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Adrenal insufficiency; chronic ASM use may affect cortisol; consider if fatigue is prominent
Bone mineral density screening for patients on long-term enzyme-inducing ASMs; fracture risk from seizures
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal T-score; osteopenia/osteoporosis → treat and modify ASM if possible

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Autoimmune epilepsy is treatable cause of apparent DRE; anti-LGI1, anti-CASPR2, anti-NMDAR, anti-GABA-B, anti-AMPA
CSF more sensitive than serum for some antibodies (NMDAR); paired serum/CSF testing recommended

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.item: Genetic epilepsy panel / Whole exome sequencing (CPT 81415, 81419)
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Genetic cause suspected if syndromic features, family history, or early onset DRE; may guide targeted therapy (e.g., SCN1A → avoid sodium channel blockers in Dravet)
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Pathogenic variants in epilepsy genes (SCN1A, SCN2A, KCNQ2, DEPDC5, TSC1/2, etc.)

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: New-onset DRE in adults >40 with cognitive decline or other neurologic symptoms; anti-Hu, anti-CV2, anti-amphiphysin

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.item: CSF glucose with paired serum glucose (CPT 82950)
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: GLUT1 deficiency syndrome: CSF glucose <40 mg/dL or CSF/serum glucose ratio <0.4; ketogenic diet is treatment of choice
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: CSF/serum ratio >0.6; low ratio → GLUT1 deficiency → ketogenic diet

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Mitochondrial epilepsy (MELAS, MERRF) if myoclonus, hearing loss, exercise intolerance, elevated lactate; avoid valproate
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Specific mutations (m.3243A>G for MELAS, m.8344A>G for MERRF)

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Wilson disease with seizures (rare); treatable cause
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Ceruloplasmin >20 mg/dL; low → 24h urine copper, slit lamp exam

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: PDC deficiency causes early-onset epilepsy responsive to ketogenic diet
Confirmatory testing for GLUT1 deficiency if low CSF glucose
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: No mutation; pathogenic variant → ketogenic diet definitive treatment

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: GLUT1 deficiency (CSF/serum ratio <0.4); infection (low CSF glucose)
Lumbar Puncture.target: Ratio >0.6; low → GLUT1 deficiency or infection

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: More sensitive than serum for NMDAR and some antibodies
Leptomeningeal malignancy if progressive DRE with other neurologic symptoms

Essential/First-line.timing: All DRE patients require dedicated epilepsy protocol MRI if not already done; includes thin-cut coronal T2/FLAIR through temporal lobes, volumetric T1, T2*, post-contrast
Essential/First-line.target: Mesial temporal sclerosis (hippocampal atrophy, T2 signal change); focal cortical dysplasia; cavernous malformation; tumor; tuberous sclerosis cortical tubers
Essential/First-line.contraindications: MRI-incompatible implants; check VNS/RNS MRI compatibility

Essential/First-line.timing: If not done recently; awake + sleep recording preferred; may capture interictal discharges to guide localization
Essential/First-line.target: Epileptiform discharges; focal vs generalized; specific syndrome features

Essential/First-line.timing: If frequent seizures, altered mental status, or concern for subclinical seizures; quantify seizure burden
Essential/First-line.target: Ictal patterns; NCSE; seizure frequency and duration

Essential/First-line.timing: Acute presentation: head trauma during seizure, prolonged postictal state, new focal deficit, anticoagulated patient
Cardiac arrhythmia vs seizure; QTc prolongation (lacosamide, rufinamide); baseline before ASM changes
Essential/First-line.target: Normal; prolonged QTc → avoid QT-prolonging ASMs

Extended.timing: **Core presurgical evaluation**: Capture habitual seizures with scalp EEG + video; confirm epileptic vs non-epileptic; localize seizure onset zone; typically 5-7 day admission
Extended.target: Ictal onset zone; seizure semiology; concordance with MRI lesion; PNES identification

Extended.timing: **Presurgical localization**: Interictal hypometabolism at seizure focus; most useful when MRI is non-lesional; obtain during seizure-free interictal state
Extended.target: Focal hypometabolism concordant with EEG focus; sensitivity 60-90% for temporal lobe epilepsy

Extended.timing: Injection during seizure onset (must have tracer ready at bedside); shows hyperperfusion at seizure focus; requires subtraction with interictal SPECT (SISCOM)
Extended.target: Focal hyperperfusion at seizure onset zone
Extended.contraindications: Requires in-unit injection within 30 sec of seizure onset

Extended.timing: Non-invasive source localization of interictal discharges; complementary to EEG; most useful for non-lesional neocortical epilepsy
Extended.target: Dipole cluster concordant with suspected focus

Extended.timing: **Required presurgical evaluation**: Lateralize and localize cognitive function; predict postoperative cognitive outcome; baseline before surgery
Extended.target: Memory lateralization; language dominance; cognitive profile consistent with seizure focus
Extended.contraindications: Requires cooperation; active seizures may invalidate

Extended.timing: Language and motor cortex mapping for presurgical planning; non-invasive alternative to Wada test for language lateralization
Extended.target: Language dominance (left, right, bilateral); proximity of eloquent cortex to planned resection

Extended.timing: Home monitoring to capture events; useful if EMU admission not yet feasible or for seizure frequency quantification
Extended.target: Ictal events; interictal discharges; seizure frequency

Extended.timing: Computer-assisted detection of subtle cortical dysplasia not visible on visual MRI review; voxel-based morphometry
Aspiration pneumonia post-seizure; ETT position if intubated

Rare/Advanced.timing: When non-invasive data is discordant or non-localizing; depth electrodes placed stereotactically to sample suspected epileptogenic zone; typically 1-3 weeks monitoring
Rare/Advanced.target: Precise ictal onset zone; propagation pathways; define resection margins

Rare/Advanced.timing: Presurgical memory and language lateralization; largely replaced by fMRI but still used when fMRI inconclusive or discordant; assesses risk of postoperative amnesia
Rare/Advanced.target: Language lateralization; memory adequacy of contralateral hemisphere
Rare/Advanced.contraindications: Contrast allergy; carotid stenosis; vascular anomalies

Rare/Advanced.timing: Improved source localization with dense array; electrical source imaging (ESI); research and specialized centers
Rare/Advanced.target: Refined dipole localization; source imaging concordant with other modalities

Rare/Advanced.timing: Pre-operative planning for laser interstitial thermal therapy; volumetric sequences to plan trajectory
Rare/Advanced.target: Target lesion (MTS, FCD, hypothalamic hamartoma) amenable to LITT

Referrals & Consults.item: Comprehensive epilepsy center referral for presurgical evaluation if seizures persist despite two or more appropriately chosen ASMs (ILAE definition of DRE met)
Epileptologist consultation for ASM optimization, rational polytherapy, and candidacy assessment for surgery/neuromodulation
Neuropsychological testing for baseline cognitive assessment and presurgical lateralization of memory and language
Psychiatry referral for depression, anxiety, or psychiatric comorbidity management (affects 30-50% of DRE patients)
Neurosurgery consultation when presurgical workup supports surgical candidacy (concordant localization data)
Registered dietitian for ketogenic diet or modified Atkins diet initiation and monitoring if pharmacotherapy insufficient
Social work referral for disability assistance, vocational rehabilitation, and community resources for patients with functional limitations from DRE
Reproductive endocrinology or OB/GYN referral for women of childbearing potential for preconception planning, ASM teratogenicity counseling, and contraception optimization
Physical therapy for fall prevention, injury management, and exercise program given recurrent seizure-related falls
Palliative care or supportive care team for patients with severe refractory epilepsy significantly impacting quality of life

Patient Instructions.item: Take all antiseizure medications exactly as prescribed; even one missed dose can trigger breakthrough seizures in DRE — use pill organizers and alarms
Ensure rescue medication (nasal midazolam or rectal diazepam) is available at all times; train household members and caregivers on administration technique
Return to ED immediately if seizure lasts >5 minutes, multiple seizures without recovery between them, seizure in water, significant head injury during seizure, or first seizure during pregnancy
Do not drive until seizure-free for state-mandated period (varies by state, typically 3-12 months); discuss driving restrictions with neurologist at each visit
Avoid swimming alone or unsupervised bathing; use showers instead of baths; avoid heights and open water without supervision due to drowning risk (leading cause of seizure-related death)
Keep a seizure diary (paper or app such as Seizure Tracker, EpiFinder) documenting date, time, duration, type, triggers, and medications taken — bring to all neurology visits
Wear a medical alert bracelet or necklace identifying epilepsy diagnosis and current medications for emergency responders

Inform prescribing physicians about all ASMs before starting any new medication; many common drugs (antibiotics, psychiatric medications) interact with ASMs and can lower seizure threshold or affect ASM levels

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Prioritize consistent sleep schedule with 7-9 hours nightly; sleep deprivation is the most potent modifiable seizure trigger — avoid shift work if possible
Avoid alcohol use; alcohol withdrawal lowers seizure threshold and alcohol interacts with ASMs; if unable to abstain, limit to ≤1 drink with food and never binge drink
Implement stress reduction techniques (mindfulness, cognitive behavioral therapy) as chronic stress increases seizure frequency through cortisol-mediated excitotoxicity
SUDEP risk reduction: optimize seizure control, ensure nocturnal supervision if possible, avoid prone sleeping position, consider seizure detection devices (watches, bed monitors)
Use reliable contraception for women of childbearing potential; enzyme-inducing ASMs (phenytoin, carbamazepine, phenobarbital) reduce efficacy of hormonal contraceptives — use IUD or barrier methods
Home safety modifications: remove sharp furniture edges, install stove guards, use microwave instead of stovetop, shower instead of bath, avoid locked bathroom doors
Consider protective headgear (SeizureGuard, Ribcap) for patients with frequent tonic or drop seizures to prevent head injury

differential.features: Subtherapeutic ASM levels; missed doses; inconsistent refills; social/financial barriers
differential.tests: ASM trough levels; pharmacy refill records; pill counts; direct questioning

differential.features: Wrong ASM for epilepsy syndrome (e.g., sodium channel blocker worsening absence or myoclonic epilepsy); diagnostic re-evaluation needed
differential.tests: Detailed seizure semiology; EEG classification (focal vs generalized); syndrome-appropriate ASM selection

differential.features: Waxing/waning movements; eyes closed; pelvic thrusting; prolonged duration; out-of-phase limb movements; lack of postictal confusion
differential.tests: Video-EEG monitoring (gold standard); postictal prolactin (normal in PNES); PNES may coexist with epilepsy in 10-20%

differential.features: New seizure onset or acceleration in previously controlled patient; cognitive decline; psychiatric symptoms; faciobrachial dystonic seizures (LGI1)
differential.tests: Autoimmune encephalitis antibody panel (serum + CSF); MRI (medial temporal T2/FLAIR signal); CSF pleocytosis

differential.features: Gradual increase in seizure frequency; new neurologic deficits; papilledema
differential.tests: MRI with contrast; compare to prior imaging; consider tumor, vascular malformation, or progressive cortical dysplasia

differential.features: Myoclonus; hearing loss; exercise intolerance; stroke-like episodes; elevated lactate; maternal inheritance
differential.tests: Serum/CSF lactate; genetic testing (m.3243A>G, m.8344A>G); muscle biopsy (ragged red fibers)

differential.features: New medication started (enzyme inducer/inhibitor); herbal supplements; grapefruit juice
differential.tests: Detailed medication reconciliation; ASM levels before and after new drug; pharmacokinetic interaction review

differential.features: Seizure clustering around menstruation (perimenstrual C1, periovulatory C2, luteal C3 patterns); may respond to hormonal therapy
differential.tests: Seizure diary with menstrual cycle mapping (3+ months); progesterone challenge; neurosteroid levels

differential.features: Progressive cognitive decline; parkinsonian features; seizures as late manifestation (Alzheimer's, frontotemporal dementia)
differential.tests: Neuropsychological testing; MRI volumetrics; FDG-PET; biomarkers (amyloid, tau)

differential.features: Preceding febrile illness → explosive onset of refractory status epilepticus; typically in children/young adults; devastatingly refractory
differential.tests: EEG (super-refractory SE); MRI (initially normal, later hippocampal/cortical changes); extensive infectious/autoimmune workup negative

differential.diagnosis: Sudden increase in seizure frequency with no medication change
differential.features: New structural lesion; autoimmune process; metabolic derangement
differential.tests: Urgent MRI; expanded labs; consider autoimmune workup

differential.features: Progressive structural lesion; stroke; post-ictal Todd paralysis (resolves)
differential.tests: Urgent neuroimaging; if Todd paralysis, should resolve within 24-48h

differential.diagnosis: Cognitive decline beyond expected ASM effects
differential.features: Autoimmune encephalitis; NCSE; neurodegenerative disease; ASM toxicity
differential.tests: Autoimmune panel; continuous EEG; neuropsychological testing; ASM levels

differential.features: ASM interaction; paradoxical seizure aggravation; withdrawal effect
differential.tests: ASM levels; review interaction profile; consider reverting change

differential.diagnosis: Psychiatric symptoms (psychosis, aggression) with seizure change
differential.features: Forced normalization; ASM psychiatric effects (perampanel, levetiracetam); autoimmune process
differential.tests: Psychiatric evaluation; EEG (forced normalization shows EEG improvement with psychiatric worsening); ASM review

differential.diagnosis: Weight loss, night sweats, new neurologic symptoms
differential.tests: Paraneoplastic antibody panel; CT chest/abdomen/pelvis; whole-body PET

evidence.recommendation: Definition of DRE: failure of 2 appropriately chosen and tolerated ASMs
Only ~5% of patients failing 2 ASMs achieve seizure freedom with further medication trials
Temporal lobectomy superior to medical therapy for mesial TLE
Delayed surgical referral worsens outcomes; early surgery recommended
VNS reduces seizure frequency ~50% in responders; efficacy improves over years
RNS achieves median 53% seizure reduction at 2 years, improving over time (long-term data)
DBS of anterior nucleus of thalamus: 69% median seizure reduction at 5 years (SANTE trial)
Cenobamate: high responder rate (21% seizure-free) in treatment-resistant focal epilepsy
Ketogenic diet effective in adult DRE; ~50% achieve >50% seizure reduction
Cannabidiol (Epidiolex) reduces seizures in Dravet and LGS
SUDEP risk increases with DRE; risk reduction strategies recommended
Presurgical evaluation should be offered to all patients meeting DRE criteria
PNES coexists with epilepsy in 10-20% of DRE patients; video-EEG essential

monitoring.frequency: Each visit; 2 weeks after dose change; with breakthrough seizures
monitoring.action: Adjust dose; assess adherence; check interactions

monitoring.frequency: Baseline; q3 months x 1 year for felbamate; q6 months for carbamazepine; annually otherwise
monitoring.action: WBC <3000 → consider ASM change; felbamate: any cytopenia → discontinue

monitoring.frequency: Baseline; q3-6 months first year; annually thereafter
monitoring.action: Elevated LFTs >3x ULN → evaluate ASM hepatotoxicity; dose adjust for renal impairment

monitoring.frequency: Baseline; q3 months for carbamazepine/oxcarbazepine/eslicarbazepine; with symptoms
monitoring.action: <130 → fluid restrict, consider ASM change; <125 → urgent correction
Deficient → supplement 2000-5000 IU daily; recheck in 3 months

monitoring.frequency: Baseline if on enzyme-inducing ASMs >2 years; repeat q2 years
monitoring.action: Osteopenia → supplement calcium/D, weight-bearing exercise; osteoporosis → bisphosphonate, consider ASM change

monitoring.frequency: Baseline; after lacosamide/rufinamide initiation; with dose changes
monitoring.action: PR >220 ms on lacosamide → dose reduce or discontinue; QT shortening on rufinamide → cardiology consult
No improvement after adequate trial → re-evaluate; consider surgical evaluation
New regurgitation → cardiology referral; consider fenfluramine discontinuation

monitoring.frequency: Baseline; q3 months while on vigabatrin
Annually; before ASM changes; if sexually active and menstrual irregularity
monitoring.action: Positive → immediate ASM safety review; high-risk OB referral; folic acid 4 mg/day
Score ≥10 → psychiatric referral; adjust ASM if contributing (levetiracetam, perampanel, phenobarbital)

disposition.criteria: Single breakthrough seizure with return to baseline; identified precipitant corrected (non-adherence, illness); subtherapeutic level corrected with loading dose; rescue medication education provided; reliable follow-up with epileptologist
Seizure cluster (≥3 seizures in 24h); prolonged postictal state (>1h); new neurologic deficit; medication change requiring monitoring; social concerns about safety
Status epilepticus or refractory seizure activity; respiratory compromise; significant head injury during seizure; hemodynamic instability
Presurgical evaluation; seizure characterization (epileptic vs PNES); ASM taper for surgery
Meets DRE criteria and has not been evaluated for surgical options; intracranial monitoring needed; complex neuromodulation candidacy assessment
Epileptologist q3 months (or more frequently during ASM changes); presurgical evaluation clinic if surgical candidate; dietitian if on dietary therapy
